On Fri, 24 Oct 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> You can use JUnit to test /anything/ for which you can build a Java client.

That's not to say you want to, of course.

JUnit is pretty simple, so it's not too hard to implement something
similar in any language out there, including things sometimes not
considered to be "real" languages (such as shell scripts or whatever).
Despite the fact that I write about 80% of my code in Java, much of my
test code is in other languages, such as shell scripts for custom-built
"languages" built with awk or similar tools.

Use some creativity, think outside of the (Java) box, and you may find
an easier way to do your testing than JUnit. (Or you may find that JUnit
works best, in which case you can go ahead and use it.)

cjs
